data.title: Debug Console should support find

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 0.10.10
- OS Version: Ubuntu 14.04

This goes along with a few other debug console feature requests that I see (ex: #3974), but it would also be nice if find worked in the debug console.

Steps to reproduce:
1. Start debugging something, have the console be full of text
2. Hit Ctrl-F to find

Result: Find works in the editor window instead of the debug console

data.title: Format Code doesn't work for an unsaved buffer
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 0.10.11
- OS Version: Windows 7

Steps to Reproduce:
- Open a new buffer (Ctrl+N)
- Set the language mode to JavaScript (Ctrl-K M)
- Type some code with wrong indentation, e.g.

```
var x = 1;
    var y = 2;
```
- Try to format the code (Alt+Shift+F)

**What happens**: Nothing.
**What is expected to happen**: Code should be formatted.

I tried to fix this bug, but realized that it might be a design issue:
- Code formatting is carried out by an external plugin (in case of JS it's the TS-Server)
- VSC issues a corresponding "format" message [formattingProvider.ts:102](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/4da8ef4e95e423071596a64b3d37c638b6700a62/extensions/typescript/src/features/formattingProvider.ts#L102) to the TS-Server consisting params of the format `{"file":null,"line":1,"offset":1,"endLine":25,"endOffset":3}`.
- The TS-Server tries to open file `null` from its `syntaxTreeCache` which leads to this error:
  
  "{"seq":0,"type":"response","command":"format","request_seq":76,"success":false,
  "message":"Error processing request. Cannot read property 'replace' of null"}"

which is caught at [formattingProvider.ts:105](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/4da8ef4e95e423071596a64b3d37c638b6700a62/extensions/typescript/src/features/formattingProvider.ts#L105) but not logged anywhere, apparently.

So the issue is, an unsaved buffer has no file path and, hence, is not accessible for the TS-Server. potentially, this might be fixed by using some internal fake path, which would be known to the TS-Server's `cacheSyntaxTree`. Apparently, a physical file is not a hard requirement. Initially I assumed, that VSC only sends a file name to the TS-Server, who reads the file, computes the range and sends the formatted code back. However, a fast test disproved this:
- save a buffer to a file
- delete file immediately from the FS 
- change the code and try to format it
- ensure it worked

So: the TS-Server uses the filename but reads the file content from some internal cache shared between VSC and TSS. This cache might be the right place to reference the unsaved buffer. But if I'm right, it's a subject for a major design change.

If you have better suggestions because I overlooked something feel free to inform me and I could make another attempt.

data.title: Linter message is hiding under the debug action control.

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: Windows10
- OS Version: 0.10.12-alpha

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Launch app and start debugging.
2. While debugging verify if any warning message displaying at the top of the line in any file or try to edit a file to generate error in code.
2. Hover over on the highlighted line to get linter message.

Actual:
1. When hover-over on the highlighted line then the linter message is displaying behind the debug action control and user can't read message at all.
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/17735796/13824627/18f70290-eb6c-11e5-9249-729df3a0c1c7.png)

Expected:
1. Debug action control should not hide any message coming up from user's action and message should always be displayed on top of it.
2. Suggestion: Debug action control should have fixed position in VScode and it should not cover editor window like how it is in Visual studio but in that case we have to compromise with editor window area.

data.title: Add just-in-time tips to discover keyboard shortcuts and other techniques in context
data.body:
VS Code has several keybindings to speed up or enhance workflow that users are unaware of.

Since it's not practical to memorize all keybindings upfront.  I believe users will benefit from just-in-time suggestions based off what they're doing in context.  (e.g. if a user is inserting the same characters repeatedly on multiple lines, we could suggest the keybinding to create multi-cursors.)

This could help users learn relevant keybindings while they work.

Perhaps this could be in the status bar or in a toast-like notification.  The key is to make it non-obtrusive and immediately relevant and thoughtful to the user's present needs.  There should be a global setting to disable it, if users don't want it.  We should also be very careful to avoid spammy suggestions that are repetitive or irrelevant.

@waderyan also had a similar idea before this about introducing tips into the product.  I propose we extend his idea to be in context.

data.title: [js] No color to variables not in the same line as var
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 0.10.11
- OS Version: Ubuntu 14.04
- Theme: Dark+ (dark default)

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Create file test.js
2. Add code to test.js

```
var a = 1, b = 2,
      c = 3, d = 4;
```

The a and b variables get colored (light blue on this theme), the c and d variables get no color (white on this theme).

Also, whe you use the variable it get no special color, but I'm not sure if this is intended. I would prefer it colored as well.

All variables get no color, nor the console.log (the hole line is white on this theme):

```
console.log(a,b,c,d);
```

data.title: Single quote in JSX breaks vscode code formatting
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 0.10.11
- OS Version: Win 7, Mac OS 10.11.3

Steps to Reproduce:

If there is a single quote inside JSX, code formatting does not work for the entire file. Furthermore, if such a file is opened and tried code formatting, it breaks for all other files until a vscode restart.

Sample:

```
class Sample extends Component {
    render() {
        <View style={styles.container}>
            <Text style={styles.title}>Don't</Text>
        </View>
    }
}
```

First reported by @taypo: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-react-native/issues/156

data.title: Intellisense parameter help popup reappears after dismissing it

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 0.10.12
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:
In the following code, toDoListItem is an array. 

```
$scope.AddItem = function (data) {
    $scope.toDoListItem.push
```

When I write the code to push new items on to the array I get the intellisense parameter help. I press Esc to dismiss the tooltip and fill in the rest of the code to add elements to the array. I pass in a small JSON object with two fields. As soon as I type the ',' to enter the second field of the object, the parameter help tooltip appears again, obscuring the code that I have written. I press Esc again to dismiss the parameter help.

I expected the parameter help not to come back up while I was writing code inside this block.

See this animated gif for more details:
![popup](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1704059/13817868/b6513636-eb8b-11e5-9f70-2f3fd8d792b6.gif)

Found while testing: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/3715

data.title: [html] Typing "<something.hidden" in an HTML file will hide the entered text
data.body:
Typing "<something.hidden" in an HTML file will hide the entered text. I was very surprised to see this happening, while coding a TYPO3 Fluid template in VS Code. I reduced it to the reproducable steps below.
- VSCode Version: 0.10.11
- OS Version: OSX El Capitan 10.11.3

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Create an HTML file
2. Type `<foo.hidden`
3. Watch `foo.hidden` disappear

2. Click on same stack frame from an internal module - an in-memory editor is opened
3. Ctrl-tab, Ctrl-tab you are back in the in-memory editor, but the view state is not preserved the cursor is at the beginning of the file

data.title: Document edits from an extension and the Undo stack
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 0.10.11, 10.10 & 10.8
- OS Version: Win 8.1

Steps to Reproduce:
1. In a document, type some text.
2. Invoke a command from an extension that makes an edit to the document. (With `TextEditor.edit()`)
3. Press ctrl+z to undo

Would expect steps 1 & 2 to produce separate entries in the undo stack: the edit from (2) to be undone, and the text edit in (1) only with a further undo.
However the undo removes both the edit from (2) and the text from (1)

If, in between steps 1 & 2, you move the text cursor, then 2 separate entries to the undo stack _are_ created, as expected.

Can provide a sample extension if necessary.

data.title: trying to type a tab character over a sequence of spaces results in unexpected behaviour
data.body:
If I want to align the two comments in the following snippet, I would select the spaces between the ';' and '/' and replace them with one or more tabs. In VS Code this results in an unexpected behaviour: the whole lines are indented by one tab instead of replacing the selected spaces with a tab.  

``` js
var foo = 123;       // this is a comment
var bar = 4;       // another comment
```
